body:
1) Have you installed ray with `pip install ray`?
2) Are you sure ray is compatible with your OS?
3) Are you sure you installed ray into the python venv which you are using?
Hey @MarijnQ, is it possible to upgrade to Python 3.7 or newer? We are officially dropping support for Python 3.6 in Ludwig 0.5, so it may be that some dependency packages are not supported in 3.6.

> 

@tgaddair Thanks for your reply, this was my mistake, I'm sorry, I am currently on 3.7.13 and I will change that in the issue.

Thanks @MarijnQ, looking at your example, it looks like the issue may actually not be related to ray, necessarily. I suspect the model you're trying to load was trained with Ludwig v0.4 and tensorflow, is that right? In Ludwig v0.5, we've updated Ludwig to use PyTorch.

For the `experiment` call, it looks like the issue is that the param `--config_file` was changed to `--config`. Can you try changing that param and try again?

It is curious that you have Ray installed and yet it is complaining about it not being available. I am not immediately sure why that's happening, but I will see if I can repro that specific issue on our side.

Glad that worked! I'm guessing the issue you're running into is that your PyTorch version isn't able to use the GPU in your Collab notebook. Can you try running the following to check this?

```
import torch
print(torch.cuda_is_available())
```

If it prints False, you can try re-installing torch with GPU support:

```
pip install torch torchvision torchaudio --extra-index-url https://download.pytorch.org/whl/cu113
```

Then restart the notebook and try running the `cuda_is_available()` check again. If it prints True, then you should be able to use the GPU in Ludwig.

@tgaddair Thanks for the replay again, really appreciate it.
The issue is unfortunately not resolved as I get neither True or False.
I followed your steps and I got error code:
`AttributeError: module 'torch' has no attribute 'cuda_is_available'`

I tried running it on TPU, GPU and on the Google Colab native runtype. But no success on either of these.

No problem, @MarijnQ!

Can you try running `!nvcc --version` to see what version of CUDA is being run in your notebook? That will help us decide which version of PyTorch needs to be installed.

@MarijnQ 
Since you're running your code on Google Colab, have you checked if a cloud GPU or TPU has been assigned to your runtime? I can't give the directions from the top of my head, but you should google how to run torch models on Colab cloud GPU-s or TPU-s.

This is the response @tgaddair ,

nvcc: NVIDIA (R) Cuda compiler driver
Copyright (c) 2005-2020 NVIDIA Corporation
Built on Mon_Oct_12_20:09:46_PDT_2020
Cuda compilation tools, release 11.1, V11.1.105
Build cuda_11.1.TC455_06.29190527_0

Hey @MarijnQ, it looks like your notebook is GPU-capable. Another thing you can check is GPU visibility with `nvidia-smi`.

Apologies, I sent you the wrong torch command earlier. Can you actually run `torch.cuda.is_available()` and share the output?
